alert.note: Alert for Koochiching (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Duluth (Northeast Minnesota and Northern Wisconsin)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued June 10 at 5:15PM CDT until June 15 at 4:00PM CDT by NWS Duluth
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues. Namakan and Rainy Lake have both surpassed levels set during the 2014 peak levels with Rainy Lake now above the 1950 record peak as well. * WHERE...Portions of north central Minnesota and northeast Minnesota, including the following counties, in north central Minnesota, Koochiching. In northeast Minnesota, St. Louis. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...Flooding of lakes, rivers, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is occurring. Several structures are flooded and sand bagging operations are continuing. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 506 PM CDT, Friday, emergency management continued to reported flooding in the warned area. - The dry weather over the past week has meant declining flows in the smaller streams and reduced inflows to the lakes. The 4-day forecast includes chances of showers and thunderstorm with one-tenth up to three-tenths of an inch of rain expected across the basin. Even with this rainfall, the expectation is that the recent decreases of inflow will continue. There is some rain in the forecast beyond four days, but amounts remain uncertain. Flows across most of the watershed are expected to remain very high for the week ahead. Namakan and Kabetogama Lakes were at 1122.2 feet as of June 10, which is 20 inches above the peak level set in 2014 and 7.5 inches below the 1916 peak. The level of Namakan Lake is expected to fall by 9 to 12 inches between June 10 and June 17. Rainy Lake was at 1113.2 feet as of June 10 which is 22 inches above the 2014 flooding peak and 3 inches above the previous record peak of 1950. The level of Rainy Lake is expected to remain stable with slight fluctuations up or down depending on rainfall by six-tenths of an inch between June 10 and June 17. Rainy Lake should reach its peak by around June 17 unless more rainfall occurs than currently expected. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... International Falls, Kabetogama, Crane Lake, Kabetogama Lake, Voyageurs National Park, Rainy Lake - East, Rainy Lake - West, northwestern Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, Ranier, Ray, Island View, Ericksburg, Johnson Lake, and Sand Point Lake. - For more information about flood safety visit, https://weather.gov/safety/flood . For more information about the Rainy Lake Basin flooding visit, https://weather.gov/dlh/RainyRiverBasin .
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Once levels have peaked, it will take a matter of weeks to a month for levels to decline to near normal summer levels. Additional rainfall will prolong the time it takes for levels to recede.
